text:
S-X2
734. Taylor Winifred M. (Mrs. William)
1. Your full name: [Name]
2. Your address: [Address]
3. Date: [Date]
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation? [Occupation]
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) [Month, Year]
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. [Dates]
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to state if you are in my teens, etc.) [Age]
9. What were your reasons for coming West? [Reasons]
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other peoples? Reading about it?) [Method]

11. What did you know about the West? [Knowledge]
12. How did you feel about the West? [Feelings]
Taylor, Winifred M. (Mrs. William)
Box 55, Paynton.

To Bank. - April 19, 1952

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name ...............................................................
2. Your address ........................................................................
3. Date ......................................................................................
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ........
5. What was your father's name and occupation? .....................
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ....
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. ..................................................
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to say how long you have been here.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (Give at least two reasons.) ..................................................................

10. Have you learned about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

11. If you have information available regarding the pioneer colony movement, could you please share it with the Board of Directors?

12. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

13. If you have information available regarding the pioneer colony movement, could you please share it with the Board of Directors?
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   We traveled with my husband and our family of seven children.

13. What means of transportation did you use? SS. Take hundreds from thousands
    to days ahead of all normal family

14. What kind of transportation did you need? SS. Take hundreds from thousands

15. Were there any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land? E-47-21w4of Paynter's farm

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

19. What did you do during your first year in Western Canada?

20. After my marriage - 6 miles S. of Paynter's farm 1912-1913

21. Plan Paynter's farm - 1909-1911

22. How much time did you work in 1944?

23. How much time did you work in 1944?
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
   We traveled with the advance band of homesteaders.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We used horse-drawn wagons.

14. How long did the journey take?
   The journey took about two months.

15. What difficulties did you encounter during the journey?
   We encountered many difficulties, including bad weather, lack of food, and sickness.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   We settled near the village of Paynton.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   After my marriage - 6 miles S.E. of Paynton.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Worked at P. Paynton farm from 1909-1910. My husband also worked there from 1905-1910. He came from England and was a farmer. His homestead - 8 mi. N.W. of Sexsmith. He farmed there until his death in 1944.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How far by what means of travel?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled & why would & how.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? If so, please do so.

work of pioneer

will turn on all homesteads a mound about two and a half feet high.
13. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910 - A. E. Hanchey family

26. If you owned a car before 1910, when did you buy it? What make was it?

27. Have you had any trading business? Yes, I have had several businesses.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new owners)

29. How often did you shop in the city away from home by automobile?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays about 1914-1915?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to worry about the condition of your clothes? Probably early 1920s when you started working.

32. What (if ever) did you first begin to worry about the state of the roads?

33. When you came to Sebastopol, the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make his decision?

34. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910 - A. T. W. bought one.

26. If so, what was the make? Ford.

27. How far from your house is Bathurst? 40 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade (Indicate any changes due to new terms, etc.)?

29. How often did you shop in town? Every week.

30. What (if any) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Bathurst.

31. What (if any) did people in your district start buying through the mail order catalogues?

32. Had a good supply of clothing? Yes.

33. Was there a good selection of goods? Yes.

34. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1920

35. When did you first go to Sherrington? 1919

36. Did you ever try to buy a house? No.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 193 or what reasons did they have for moving? (A few—mostly Bachelor homesteaders who sold their farms under the tax levy on taxes. They bought tax money, let the taxes go outstanding, and then for sale.)

35. How many were too well established to want to leave? (Conditions there were no worse than elsewhere. Each tax levy was 2% hit on anyone owning property over $600.)

36. If you or someone in your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates where possible. My husband Wm. Taylor: Alder Town School/Board of Education (1914-1920), Supervisor of Education (1915-1920).

37. Any connection to the railroad or any other transportation? (None)

First R.O.: First Church Services

First Pop. in Poynton about March 1907

Second Pop. in Poynton about March 1908

Next (after 1909):

Povton was named after Peter Poateson of Old Timesan 1886

Quota Mills School—Now named Mr. Taylor town freemaster (4 miles east of Povnton).
34. Had any people moved away during the 1930/37 Did many return?

35. How many were born well established to want to leave? + conditions here were no worse than elsewhere.

36. If so, what members of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organization? Mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My father, Postmaster 1904-1908, a great friend to youth.

Sons, William Taylor, Alderney Hill School Board 1914-1944

My husband, Wm. Taylor, Alderney Hill School Board 1914-1944

Sons, Payton, farm owner, 1915-1920

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "in" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving date whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, graduating the first college, etc.)

First P.O. 1904, First Church Services 1904

First Baptist Church, William Stone, farm 1905

First Public School in Payton, opened March 19th, 1906

Reginald Saunders, farm 1907

Donald Saunders, farm 1907

Mary Thornton

Payton was named after Peter Payton, an old farmer.

Payton was settled in 1904.

Alden School - named after Geo. Taylor, farm 4 mile east of Payton.

After his death - our farm was called "Payton" because of his name and work ethic.

Addressed always to avoid confusion.
43. Questions regarding historical materials:

Would you or the person who owns these letters

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archives for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Office at the legislature

Library, Rights of the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(declare your preferences, if any)

...............

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Name

Address

City

Province

Postal Code

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came west

Constitutional School Act was passed 1905 and 1906

G. H. Rollason Grand Trunk 1905 and 1906

J. A. Bannatyne 1907

Chaplain's residence opened 1907

Highway No. 3 Roman Catholic 1923

Changes to road and farming

School can't stand snowing

J. David E. Hall, Secretary
Would you or the person who owns this either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library? (Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Nine children
Seventeen grandchildren

Sons
Daughters
4 3 3 6

Snr. Owen

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Consolidated School 4 rooms Paynton 1923
C. P. Railway Grade built 1904 laid 1905
First train July 1st 1905 my mother lived in the
three fine old houses on William 1907
Highway No. 5
Roman Catholic 1923 school
Change to mechanized farming
Motor Car + Truck Travel

Please give the name and address of other persons who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person:

_________________________
William W. and Marjorie Taylor
father: Bill & Ann - Paynton, Sask.

Children:
1913 William Andrew Taylor
1915 Earl Samuel Taylor
1917 and William Clayton Anderson - Victoria BC.
1919 Marjorie Joyce Bulten - Newbury
1926 Peter Ray Taylor
1929 Harold Anderson Taylor - Vancouver
1934 Dorothy Joan Taylor - Highwood
1936 David Charles Taylor - N. Battleford

Grandchildren:
1924 Charles William Taylor
1930 Neville M. Taylor
1947 Edward George Taylor

Farmers:
1931 John William Andrews - Victoria BC.
1949 Marjorie Taylor - North Battleford
1950 Ethel Ann Taylor - Victoria BC.

1947 Gordon E. Sutton
1949 Barbara Ann
1951 David Taylor
1949 Marjorie Ann Taylor (twins)
1950 Ernest Wilson

1947 Darlene P. Taylor - Vancouver
